articles.headline: Adding to the List of Worries, Signs That Inflation Is Bubbling Up
articles.snippet: A pick-up in prices will complicate efforts by the Federal Reserve as it tries to stave off a slowdown in economic growth.
articles.abstract: A pick-up in prices will complicate efforts by the Federal Reserve as it tries to stave off a slowdown in economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economists and central bankers have worried for months that soaring food and energy costs could lead to higher inflation, but investors had shrugged off those concerns, preferring to focus on the slowdown in growth.

articles.headline: Ethiopians Said to Push Civilians Into Rebel War
articles.snippet: The Ethiopian government, a top U.S. ally, is said to be forcing teachers, doctors and aid workers to fight rebels.
articles.abstract: The Ethiopian government, a top U.S. ally, is said to be forcing teachers, doctors and aid workers to fight rebels.

articles.headline: Ethanol’s Issue: Getting Acquainted With Drivers
articles.snippet: The industry is experiencing a historic boom, yet ethanol remains a mystery to the motoring public, even in states that have pushed it hardest.
articles.abstract: The industry is experiencing a historic boom, yet ethanol remains a mystery to the motoring public, even in states that have pushed it hardest.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Ohio  If America’s great ethanol fuel experiment is ever going to work, Bill Timmermeister will be among the first to know.

articles.headline: In China, Farming Fish in Toxic Waters
articles.snippet: China is the biggest producer and exporter of seafood in the world, but contaminated water has created serious food safety and environmental problems.
articles.abstract: China is the biggest producer and exporter of seafood in the world, but contaminated water has created serious food safety and environmental problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: FUQING, China  Here in southern China, beneath the looming mountains of Fujian Province, lie dozens of enormous ponds filled with murky brown water and teeming with eels, shrimp and tilapia, much of it destined for markets in Japan and the West.

articles.headline: Small Shops See Smallness as Their Big Selling Point
articles.snippet: Most small retailers, which cannot afford either price cuts or expensive advertising, are doing something else this holiday season: making a virtue of their size.
articles.abstract: Most small retailers, which cannot afford either price cuts or expensive advertising, are doing something else this holiday season: making a virtue of their size.
articles.lead_paragraph: Predictions of a weak holiday shopping season have led the big department stores to slash prices and stretch their advertising budgets. But most small retailers, which cannot afford either the price cuts or the expensive advertising, are doing something else this year: making a virtue of their size.

articles.headline: Money Goes Far in New York, if You’re European
articles.snippet: With the dollar near its lowest rate ever against the euro, many Europeans are looking at the United States as a cheap place to flex their strong currency.
articles.abstract: With the dollar near its lowest rate ever against the euro, many Europeans are looking at the United States as a cheap place to flex their strong currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Margaret Dragonette arrived in New York last week  three nieces, a cousin and loads of empty luggage in tow. By the time Ms. Dragonette, an administrative assistant for a nonprofit in Liverpool, was heading home, her group had filled six large suitcases and five carry-on bags. The bags were so stuffed with Juicy Couture T-shirts, Guess watches and Croc sandals that her nieces would have to wear the Ugg boots she was giving them for Christmas on the plane.
articles.byline: By Kate Hammer and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: In a Mess, Yes, but She’s Got a Plan
articles.snippet: The person who spurred the government to action concerning the subprime mortgage mess was not Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. It was Sheila C. Bair.
articles.abstract: The person who spurred the government to action concerning the subprime mortgage mess was not Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. It was Sheila C. Bair.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sheila C. Bair never expected to find herself in the middle of the subprime mortgage mess.

articles.headline: Climate Plan Looks Beyond Bush’s Tenure
articles.snippet: An agreement reached Saturday pushes debates on U.S. participation into the administration of a new president.
articles.abstract: An agreement reached Saturday pushes debates on U.S. participation into the administration of a new president.
articles.lead_paragraph: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  The world’s faltering effort to cut greenhouse gas emissions got a new lease on life on Saturday, as delegates from 187 countries agreed to negotiate a new accord over the next two years  pushing the crucial debates about United States participation into the administration of a new American president.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Andrew C. Revkin

articles.headline: Obama Showing New Confidence With Iowa Sprint
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama is threatening Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s long dominance even as he faces intensified questions about his vulnerabilities.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama is threatening Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s long dominance even as he faces intensified questions about his vulnerabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Iowa  Senator Barack Obama is seeking to capitalize on a moment of opportunity in the weeks before the Iowa caucuses to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s long dominance of the Democratic field, and in doing so, he now faces intensified questions about his vulnerabilities in a general election.

articles.headline: Never Mind What’s in Them, Bags Are the Fashion
articles.snippet: Once a flimsy afterthought in American retailing, the lowly, free store bag is undergoing a luxurious makeover.
articles.abstract: Once a flimsy afterthought in American retailing, the lowly, free store bag is undergoing a luxurious makeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: A team of designers at Saks Fifth Avenue envisioned “a piece of modern art” and hired a renowned graphic artist to create it. Their counterparts at Lord & Taylor demanded five prototypes, even traveling to a Korean factory to oversee manufacturing.

articles.headline: Quick, Call Tech Support for the S.E.C.
articles.snippet: A government report highlights shortcomings in the Securities and Exchange Commission’s efforts to battle insider trading and market manipulation.
articles.abstract: A government report highlights shortcomings in the Securities and Exchange Commission’s efforts to battle insider trading and market manipulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S no secret that the Securities and Exchange Commission is terrifically understaffed and wildly underfunded compared with the populous and wealthy Wall Street world it is supposed to police. But a report by the Government Accountability Office to be released Monday indicates that in its battles against insider trading and market manipulation, the commission declines to use one of the sharpest tools in its arsenal: the internal audits conducted by the nation’s stock and options exchanges.

articles.headline: The Stay-at-Home Woman Travels Well
articles.snippet: Getting out her husband’s message through small talk, Ann Romney has grown into the role of the most visible Republican wife.
articles.abstract: Getting out her husband’s message through small talk, Ann Romney has grown into the role of the most visible Republican wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNT Pleasant, S.C.

articles.headline: Google Gets Ready to Rumble With Microsoft
articles.snippet: The growing confrontation promises to be an epic battle that shapes the prosperity and progress of both companies.
articles.abstract: The growing confrontation promises to be an epic battle that shapes the prosperity and progress of both companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mountain View, Calif.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Where Water-Cooler Talk Is About the Water Bowl
articles.snippet: Employees explain the benefits of bringing their dogs to work.
articles.abstract: Employees explain the benefits of bringing their dogs to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: A dog’s life  at the office: Three employees who are allowed to bring their dogs to work talked about the benefits it offers for themselves, their co-workers and the pets.
articles.byline: As told to Patricia R. Olsen

articles.headline: A Warning From Behind the Curtain
articles.snippet: Media consumers have been watching the writers’ strike from the sidelines, but they might take notice if the awards season is replaced by marches and pickets.
articles.abstract: Media consumers have been watching the writers’ strike from the sidelines, but they might take notice if the awards season is replaced by marches and pickets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Golden Globe nominations were announced on Thursday, glimmering tributes to the likes of Tom Hanks, Denzel Washington and Cate Blanchett. But on the same day, all that glitters in Hollywood was buried beneath a blizzard of arcane initials.

articles.headline: In ’08 Race, the Other Clinton Steps Up Publicly
articles.snippet: Bill Clinton is not running his wife’s campaign, but he has become the most powerful force in the operation besides her.
articles.abstract: Bill Clinton is not running his wife’s campaign, but he has become the most powerful force in the operation besides her.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNLAP, Iowa  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign advisers laid out their new political strategy in a private conference call with allies last Tuesday, Bill Clinton was not on the line. He did not need to be. The message being delivered was his.

articles.headline: Retailers Face an Ominous Holiday Sign
articles.snippet: Sales of women’s clothing, a traditional pillar of the holiday shopping season, are unusually weak so far this year, according to a major credit card company.
articles.abstract: Sales of women’s clothing, a traditional pillar of the holiday shopping season, are unusually weak so far this year, according to a major credit card company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales of women’s clothing, a traditional pillar of the holiday shopping season, are unusually bleak so far this year, according to a major credit card company, an ominous sign for the retail industry.

articles.headline: Counterfeit Drugs’ Path Eased by Free Trade Zones
articles.snippet: Counterfeiters use free trade zones to hide a drug’s provenance or to make or relabel adulterated products.
articles.abstract: Counterfeiters use free trade zones to hide a drug’s provenance or to make or relabel adulterated products.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Along a seemingly endless row of identical gray warehouses, a lone guard stands watch over a shuttered storage area with a peeling green and yellow sign: Euro Gulf Trading.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Candidates Scrambling to Cope With Rise of Huckabee
articles.snippet: In weekend campaigning, Mike Huckabee’s ascendancy rippled across the Republican field.
articles.abstract: In weekend campaigning, Mike Huckabee’s ascendancy rippled across the Republican field.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Michael Cooper, Michael Luo, Marc Santora and Paul Vitello and written by Mr. Cooper.

articles.headline: Old U.S. Allies, Still Hiding in Laos
articles.snippet: Thousands of jungle warriors hired by the C.I.A. during the Vietnam War live in fear of the Laotian government.
articles.abstract: Thousands of jungle warriors hired by the C.I.A. during the Vietnam War live in fear of the Laotian government.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE PROVINCE, Laos  They call themselves America’s forgotten soldiers.

articles.headline: For Recipients of Medicare, the Hard Sell
articles.snippet: Federal officials are trying to cut down on aggressive or deceptive sales pitches for Medicare Advantage plans.
articles.abstract: Federal officials are trying to cut down on aggressive or deceptive sales pitches for Medicare Advantage plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Miss.  Dorothy K. Barksdale, a 70-year-old seamstress, vividly remembers the day an insurance agent visited her home and signed her up for a private Medicare health plan.

articles.headline: Faster Chips Are Leaving Programmers in Their Dust
articles.snippet: Newer computer chips with multiple processors require dauntingly complex software and programmers are having a hard time keeping up.
articles.abstract: Newer computer chips with multiple processors require dauntingly complex software and programmers are having a hard time keeping up.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.  When he was chief executive of Intel in the 1990s, Andrew S. Grove would often talk about the “software spiral”  the interplay between ever-faster microprocessor chips and software that required ever more computing power.

articles.headline: Case Lays Bare the Media’s Reliance on Iraqi Journalists
articles.snippet: Bilal Hussein is an Iraqi photographer who had a hand in The Associated Press’s 2005 Pulitzer Prize for photography before being jailed without charges by the U.S. military.
articles.abstract: Bilal Hussein is an Iraqi photographer who had a hand in The Associated Press’s 2005 Pulitzer Prize for photography before being jailed without charges by the U.S. military.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bilal Hussein, an Iraqi photographer who had a hand in The Associated Press’s 2005 Pulitzer Prize for photography before being jailed without charges by the United States military, finally had a day in court last week. But his story, which highlights the unprecedented role that Iraqis are playing in news coverage of the war, is really just beginning.

articles.headline: Changing Courses at the Food Network
articles.snippet: Having taken food and chefs from what was once the domain of public television to new celebrity heights, the Food Network is now undergoing a transformation.
articles.abstract: Having taken food and chefs from what was once the domain of public television to new celebrity heights, the Food Network is now undergoing a transformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can find chef Emeril Lagasse’s name and face all over a dozen cookbooks, 10 restaurants, lines of pots and pans, knives, Wedgwood dishes, spices, salad dressings and pasta sauces, and even a deep fryer.
